author: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
title: China’s Weapon Tests Close to a ‘Sputnik Moment,’ U.S. General Says
description: Gen. Mark A. Milley said China’s testing of a hypersonic missile “has all of our attention.”
content: WASHINGTON — China’s testing of a hypersonic missile designed to evade American nuclear defenses was “very close” to a “Sputnik moment” for the United States, Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Wednesday in the first official confirmation of how Beijing’s demonstration of its weapon capabilities had taken American officials by surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Nor’easter Brings Hurricane-Force Winds to Massachusetts
description: After battering the New York area, the storm knocked out electricity to hundreds of thousands of customers across New England on Wednesday.
content: BOSTON — Hurricane-force winds from an early-season nor’easter swept through coastal New England on Wednesday, a day after battering the New York City area, sending trees crashing onto power lines and cutting electricity to hundreds of thousands of households.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: ‘Zero Risk’ Security Constraints Put U.S. Diplomats at a Disadvantage, Blinken Says
description: The State Department is easing some restrictions after employees said that their jobs overseas were harder than they needed to be.
content: WASHINGTON — It was known at the State Department as the Benghazi hangover: strict security protocols to protect U.S. officials abroad from terrorism that, in practice, limited their interactions with people in the countries where they served.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Glenn Youngkin vs. Toni Morrison
description: Picking a fight over “Beloved” and the great Toni Morrison is an unwinnable battle.
content: Glenn, you, sir, are no match for Mother Toni.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democrats Hammer Out Novel Plan to Tax Billionaires and Corporate Giants
description: New proposals would fund social and climate programs by tapping billionaires’ unrealized gains and by ensuring that the biggest companies cannot avoid income taxes altogether.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats rushed on Tuesday to nail down the details of a groundbreaking tax on billionaires’ wealth, part of an elaborate menu of tax increases to finance a significantly scaled-back bill that would strengthen the social safety net and address climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
title: G.O.P. Attack Involving Toni Morrison Novel Inflames Virginia Contest
description: A Republican ad featured a mother who had tried to have “Beloved” banned from her son’s curriculum. Democrats saw a coded racist message.
content: ARLINGTON, Va. — In the final days of the tight race for Virginia governor, the candidates are turning to the unlikeliest of campaign props: a novel from 1987.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
title: Facebook tells employees to preserve all communications for legal reasons.
description: The move follows intense scrutiny after a whistle-blower provided documents about the social network’s inner workings.
content: Facebook has told employees to “preserve internal documents and communications since 2016” that pertain to its businesses because governments and legislative bodies have started inquiries into its operations, according to a company email sent on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: U.S. Issues First Passport With ‘X’ Gender Marker
description: The country’s first gender-neutral passport was issued to Dana Zzyym, an intersex military veteran who sued the State Department in 2015, according to Lambda Legal.
content: The United States has issued its first U.S. passport with an “X” gender marker, acknowledging the rights of people who do not identify as male or female, the State Department said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: ‘Dune’ and ‘The French Dispatch’
content: Welcome. Denis Villeneuve’s film adaptation of “Dune,” based on Frank Herbert’s 1965 sci-fi novel, is in theaters and on HBO Max this weekend. Will fans love it? Manohla Dargis calls it “a starry, sumptuous take on the novel’s first half.” Others have tried to translate the book for the screen before; here’s a guide to streaming the previous efforts, if you want to go deep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Simon Romero
title: The film’s armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, told a detective she had checked to make sure rounds were not ‘hot.’
description: When the crew took a break for lunch, the ammunition was left out on a cart on the set, Ms. Gutierrez-Reed said.
content: Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, the armorer on the “Rust” film, told a detective that the day Alec Baldwin fatally shot the movie’s cinematographer, she had checked dummy rounds and ensured they were not “hot,” according to an affidavit released on Wednesday. When the crew took a break for lunch, she told the detective, the ammunition was left out on a cart on the set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Stanford
title: What Is Your Favorite Abba Memory?
description: Next month the Swedish band will release its first new album in 40 years. We want to hear what its music means to you.
content: When did you first hear a song by Abba?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Pregnant and breastfeeding women are slower to respond to vaccination, researchers report.
description: They remain susceptible to the virus for longer after the first vaccination, but achieve a mostly normal response after the second, a study says.
content: Pregnant and breastfeeding women respond to the first dose of the coronavirus vaccines more slowly than other women, and mount a less potent defense against the virus, according to a new study. After the second dose, however, their response looks almost normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Manchin denounces the Democrats’ plan to tax billionaires as divisive.
description: The plan stakes out new territory by putting levies on unrealized gains in the value of billionaires’ liquid assets, such as stocks, bonds and cash.
content: Senate Democrats’ plan to extract hundreds of billions of dollars from the wealth of billionaires hit a major snag on Wednesday when Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, denounced it as divisive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Hodara
title: Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.: A Mixed-Income River Town (but a View Will Cost You)
description: Perched above the Hudson 20 miles north of Manhattan, Dobbs Ferry is denser than its neighbors and more diverse, with good schools and a wide spectrum of housing.
content: Back in 2009, when Robert and Marianna Albert bought their first home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., a southern Westchester County river town, their criteria matched those of many young families: good schools and a safe place to raise their four children. They spent $499,999 on a 2,496-square-foot, three-bedroom split-level, which they renovated inside and out before moving in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Bent by the Pandemic, the Graham Company Dances On
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company’s return to the Joyce Theater featured a premiere, classic repertory and an intriguing experiment in reconstruction.
content: The oldest of American dance troupes, the Martha Graham Dance Company weathered the early phases of the pandemic better than most. Its virtual offerings drew treasures from the company’s great archive and experimented with various reframings, effectively making the case for the continued relevance of Graham’s work in these times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan’s Communists Are Hardly Radical, but Make a Handy Election Target
description: They have minimal support in polls. But by teaming up with other opposition parties for the first time, they have been made a boogeyman by the unpopular party in power.
content: TOKYO — The Japan Communist Party is the oldest political party in the country. It’s the largest nonruling Communist party in the world. It’s harshly critical of China. And the Japanese authorities list it, along with ISIS and North Korea, as a threat to national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Misses the Old Facebook
description: Kimmel reminisced about the days when the social media app was “just a safe place to lose your house in a pyramid scheme.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Facebook Is Bad. Fixing It Rashly Could Make It Much Worse.
description: Lawmakers should proceed cautiously when altering the rules governing the internet.
content: The nicest thing you can say about the Health Misinformation Act, proposed in July by the Democratic senators Amy Klobuchar and Ben Ray Luján, is that it means well. The internet has been a key accelerant of widespread myths, misunderstandings and lies related to Covid-19; Klobuchar and Luján’s bill would force online companies like Facebook to crack down on false information during public health emergencies, or lose immunity from lawsuits if they don’t.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Polexit’ Drive Hits a Bump: E.U.’s Largess
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 27, 2021.
content: “You are sleepwalking toward an exit from the European Union.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Moral Chasm That Has Opened Up Between Left and Right Is Widening
description: The things that are driving us apart are going to keep driving us apart.
content: There has been a remarkable erosion in public tolerance of “offensive expression about race, gender and religion,” according to a paper Dennis Chong and Morris Levy, political scientists at the University of Southern California, and Jack Citrin, a political scientist at Berkeley, presented in September at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Did Charlie Morton Get Three Outs With a Broken Leg?
description: Morton was struck by a comebacker in Atlanta’s Game 1 win over Houston in the World Series. Three outs later, he left with a fractured fibula. When the break occurred is unknown.
content: HOUSTON — At a time when old-fashioned aces have become a rarity, Atlanta has lost one of the game’s best postseason performers for the rest of the World Series. And in a sequence of events worthy of the battle-tested hurlers of the olden days, Charlie Morton appeared to record at least one out, if not three, with a broken leg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Chip Shortage Dents Earnings at G.M. and Ford
description: The automakers said the profit outlook for the full year had improved, and higher car prices eased the impact of reduced production.
content: Two big Detroit automakers said Wednesday that the worldwide shortage of computer chips had weighed on their third-quarter earnings, but there were signs that the worst of the disruption was behind them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Higher Food Prices Hit the Poor and Those Who Help Them
description: Many households are being forced to adjust their shopping lists or seek assistance. But food banks, too, are feeling the pinch.
content: With food prices surging, many Americans have found their household budgets upended, forcing difficult choices at the supermarket and putting new demands on programs intended to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Hypnotic’ Review: The Doctor Is Dangerous
description: In Netflix’s new thriller, a depressed woman gets more than she bargained for when she starts seeing a charismatic hypnotherapist.
content: In “Hypnotic,” Jenn (Kate Siegel) is a software engineer who has been dealing with depression and loss. She tells her new hypnotherapist, Dr. Meade (Jason O’Mara), that she’d like to “pass” on his specialized form of treatment. Still, he cajoles her into a session, and when she comes back from her hypnosis, he seems eerily pleased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Sliwa falsely claims that a councilman isn’t an American citizen.
description: In one of the strangest moments of the mayoral debate, Curtis Sliwa falsely said that Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez, a Democrat from Washington Heights, was not an American citizen.
content: In one of the strangest moments of the debate, Curtis Sliwa falsely said that Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez, a Democrat from Washington Heights who is originally from the Dominican Republic, was not an American citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Dinner for 10? Make This Party Wreath.
description: This festively retro dish will delight a dinner with friends, however many you invite.
content: In my first apartment in New York, my roommates and I didn’t have a table, so we ate on the couch, side by side, squashed in front of the television with takeout containers of pad kee mao from the Thai restaurant across Second Avenue balanced on our laps. So in my next apartment, the one I lived in for more than a decade, I was determined to make up for it with a giant dining table. I had visions of people sitting for hours, passing food around, popping open bottles, getting cozy. But tables are small. Instead, I ended up with two and a half tables from my local Ikea’s deeply discounted “as is” section of damaged furniture, extended by a leaf in the center and bolted together. It wasn’t perfect, but it looked almost seamless from a distance and could comfortably seat 24 (and uncomfortably seat 26). It was ridiculous, but it was also a dream come true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Gary Shteyngart’s Pandemic Novel Is His Finest Yet
description: In “Our Country Friends,” seven friends and one nemesis gather at an estate in the Hudson Valley to wait out what they’re sure will be a quick blip in their convenient and prosperous lives.
content: It’s impossible to read Chekhov without adopting his verbs. After an afternoon with “The Portable Chekhov” (which, at 640 pages, is not portable unless you have the hands of Manute Bol), I was suddenly “fetching” the groceries and “toiling” at my work and “heaving a sigh” at the sight of a clogged shower drain which I subsequently “troubled” to unclog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: How Democrats Would Tax Billionaires to Pay for Their Agenda
description: The plan stakes out new territory by putting levies on unrealized gains in the value of billionaires’ liquid assets, such as stocks, bonds and cash.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats plan to tax the richest of the rich, hoping to extract hundreds of billions of dollars from the mountains of wealth that billionaires sit on to help pay for their social safety net and climate change policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Merck Will Share Formula for Its Covid Pill With Poor Countries
description: The company announced a licensing deal that will allow the drug, molnupiravir, to be made and sold cheaply in 105 developing nations.
content: Merck has granted a royalty-free license for its promising Covid-19 pill to a United Nations-backed nonprofit in a deal that would allow the drug to be manufactured and sold cheaply in the poorest nations, where vaccines for the coronavirus are in devastatingly short supply.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s Time for COP26. Here’s Where We Stand.
description: The leaders heading to the Glasgow climate talks have made progress in recent years. But Earth is still on track for dangerous warming unless those efforts accelerate.
content: With a pivotal United Nations climate summit in Glasgow set to begin this weekend, there’s been a barrage of new research looking at how much progress the world is actually making in the fight against climate change. And that data offers reason for both hope and alarm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner and Alan Blinder
title: Charlie Morton’s season ends with a fractured fibula.
description: The Atlanta pitcher, who was struck by a comebacker in the second inning off Yuli Gurriel’s bat, fractured his right fibula.
content: The season is over for Atlanta pitcher Charlie Morton, a master of the postseason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Should I Mix or Match My Booster Shot?
description: Health officials approved mix-and-match Covid booster shots, but didn’t say whether it’s better to switch vaccines or stick with your original shot.
content: Deciding which booster shot to get can feel a lot like a choose-your-own-adventure book — you’ve got three options, but don’t have a clue which one leads to the best outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Yosemite Falls Surges After West Coast Storms Bring Needed Rainfall
description: More than six inches of rain fell over Yosemite National Park in central California over a 36-hour period, causing the waterfall to surge after a dry summer.
content: The remnants of two storm systems that converged in drought-stricken California this week helped pump new life into one of Yosemite National Park’s most popular attractions: Yosemite Falls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Iran Will Rejoin Nuclear Talks, Top Negotiator Says
description: Negotiations on reviving the 2015 nuclear accord are to resume in November, but it is unclear if the United States will take part in them.
content: CAIRO — Iran will rejoin international talks on limiting its nuclear program before the end of November, its deputy foreign minister and chief negotiator said Wednesday, raising hopes that negotiations stalled since June by the election of a hard-line Iranian president can be revived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: 5 Abba Lovers on Why the Songs Are Still Pure Gold
description: The Swedish pop group’s tracks have been the soundtrack for fans including Slipknot’s Corey Taylor, the actor-comedian Lea DeLaria and Scissor Sisters’ Jake Shears.
content: News of Abba’s return with a new album (and stage show starring digital avatars) has the group’s followers talking — so we talked to five of the group’s notable fans. Here are edited excerpts from the interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Emissions plans fall short.
content: Ahead of a major U.N. climate summit in Glasgow next week, several governments have updated their pledges under the Paris climate agreement to do more to curb their planet-warming emissions by 2030. The plans fall far short of what’s needed to avert a dangerous rise in global temperatures, a new U.N. report said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: FEMA Says It’s Still Working to Fix Racial Disparities in Disaster Aid
description: Officials were advised last year to address inequity in relief programs. A document issued Wednesday shows they are still trying to decide how.
content: WASHINGTON — Almost a year after being urged to address racial inequity in United States disaster programs, officials are still trying to decide how to deal with the problem, according to a document issued by the Federal Emergency Management Agency on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs, Simon Romero and Graham Bowley
title: A lead projectile was recovered from the director’s shoulder, and investigators believe more live rounds were on set.
description: Sheriff Adan Mendoza of Santa Fe County said at a news conference on Wednesday that the lead projectile Alec Baldwin fired from a revolver on the “Rust” film set, killing the film’s cinematographer and wounding its director, was recovered from the director’s shoulder, and added that investigators believe they recovered more live rounds on the set.
content: Sheriff Adan Mendoza of Santa Fe County said at a news conference on Wednesday that the lead projectile Alec Baldwin fired from a revolver on the “Rust” film set, killing the film’s cinematographer and wounding its director, was recovered from the director’s shoulder, and added that investigators believe they recovered more live rounds on the set.

title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Skateboarding, Six-Word Memoirs and Spooky Season
description: Each Wednesday we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to explore the world of skateboarding, write a six-word memoir about their pandemic experience, and try their hand at the New York Times Spelling Bee game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Reopens the Last Czar’s Palace, a Century After His Execution
description: The last home of Nicholas II has been restored and opened to the public as a museum outside of St. Petersburg.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Maria Ryadova recalled being in a dusty room inside the Alexander Palace, hopping from one floor beam to another and peering into the dark chasm beneath, on the day she and her team of workers made a momentous discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Shut Out on Budget Bill, Republicans Take Shots From the Sidelines
description: The party is stepping up its attacks on the safety net measure that Democrats are shaping entirely on their own.
content: WASHINGTON — The biggest legislative negotiation in years is taking place on Capitol Hill and at the White House, with key holdouts shuttling back and forth, lawmakers locked in intense private meetings and the news media providing minute-by-minute coverage of the developments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The district attorney said earlier that she had not ruled out criminal charges.
description: The Santa Fe County district attorney said on Tuesday that she was not ruling out criminal charges in last week’s fatal shooting.

author: By Katie Glueck, Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: 5 takeaways from the second N.Y.C. mayoral debate.
description: In the final contest before Election Day, Eric Adams and Curtis Sliwa traded insults and sketched out starkly different visions for the city.
content: The final debate in the New York City mayor’s race devolved into a chaotic contest Tuesday night marked by name-calling, lecturing, personal remarks and even profanity as the long-shot Republican candidate, Curtis Sliwa, sought to knock Eric Adams, the Democratic nominee, off-kilter at every turn.

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: In Virginia, Early Voting Has an Impact. And a Long Run.
description: The pandemic has helped convert more and more voters into early voters, as hundreds of thousands of Virginians have made clear in recent weeks.
content: In the tight race for governor of Virginia, Election Day has morphed into Election Month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Transgender Athletes Face Bans From Girls’ Sports in 10 U.S. States
description: Over the past two years, nine states have enacted laws to bar transgender girls and women from competing in girls’ and women’s sports. Another relied on an executive order for a ban.
content: Texas has become the latest, and the most populous, state to bar transgender girls from participating in girls’ sports at public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Dan Hinkel
title: Before Kyle Rittenhouse’s Murder Trial, a Debate Over Terms Like ‘Victim’
description: Legal experts said the term “victim” could appear prejudicial during self-defense cases. Mr. Rittenhouse shot three men, killing two, during protests against police violence in Kenosha, Wis.
content: A judge’s decision that the word “victim” generally could not be used in court to refer to the people shot by Kyle Rittenhouse after protests in Kenosha, Wis., last year drew widespread attention and outrage this week. But legal experts say that determining who should be considered a victim — in a case that hinges on Mr. Rittenhouse’s assertion of self-defense — is at the center of what jurors must decide in his trial, expected to begin next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Edgar Wright on ‘Last Night in Soho’ and the Trap of Nostalgia
description: The “Baby Driver” director’s latest film is a thriller that explores the darker side of 1960s London and questions stories that glamorize the era.
content: When Edgar Wright has an idea for a new film, it consumes him until he is finally able to make it. As he put it recently, “There’s a certain point where the movie chooses you — it haunts you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘The Mother’ Rises Up Again in the Name of Revolution
description: The Wooster Group’s production will prompt discussions about the company’s vision for Brecht’s “learning play.”
content: There’s a bit of an echo when the actors in the Wooster Group’s production of “The Mother” speak. At first I assumed that their voices were being digitally filtered. This would have been par for the course for the company, whose longstanding affinity for technological wizardry is well known. And it would have been an ingenious idea for a Bertolt Brecht play, reinforcing the alienation effect the playwright sought by subtly reminding us we were watching a show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: First, Rain. Now, Wind.
description: The nor’easter delivers a nasty changeup as it overstays its welcome.
content: It’s Wednesday. We’ll track the still-blustery nor’easter that has been swirling over the New York area for more than 36 hours. We’ll also catch up on the second mayoral debate. And we’ll hear from our restaurant critic, Pete Wells, who has rediscovered Midtown.

content: HOUSTON — With the clock ticking on the expiration of the labor agreement between Major League Baseball’s club owners and players, the leaders of both groups reiterated on Tuesday their desires to avoid a work stoppage.

content: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — When Narges and her younger sisters were finally allowed to return to school last month, they braced for the new world outside their family’s gate.

description: Some Japanese who have gone abroad and been exposed to the benefits of cannabis derivatives, particularly CBD, are hoping Japan will change course. But the government shows little inclination.
content: KOBE, Japan — From an early age, Japanese society had conditioned Takayuki Miyabe to fear marijuana. But that was before his infant daughter was diagnosed with a rare form of epilepsy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why This Billionaire Is Worried About Green Investing
description: The world is facing an energy credit crunch in part because of Wall Street’s E.S.G. focus, warned Steve Schwarzman of Blackstone.
content: Steve Schwarzman, Blackstone’s billionaire co-founder, became the latest financier to sound the alarm about an energy crunch. (The most recent sign: U.S. oil prices hit $85 a barrel this week, a seven-year high.) Speaking at the Future Investment Initiative conference in Saudi Arabia, he warned that an energy shortage could lead to “real unrest” across the world — and put forward a provocative culprit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: How to watch tonight’s game.
description: First pitch is scheduled for 8:09 p.m. Eastern time.
content: The options for Game 2 are eerily similar to those for watching Game 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa and Malik Rainey
title: Tour the Old Steel Town at the Center of ‘Lackawanna Blues’
description: In his Broadway play, Ruben Santiago-Hudson revisits the Lackawanna, N.Y., of his youth. A lot has changed since the late 1950s and ’60s, reflected here in recent photographs of the area.
content: Today, it’s Tifft Nature Preserve, a 264-acre refuge in Buffalo, just north of Lackawanna, N.Y. In the 1950s and ’60s, it was an industrial site of train tracks, grain elevators and a handful of small ponds. That area is where Ruben Santiago-Hudson — the writer, director and star of “Lackawanna Blues,” on Broadway through Nov. 12 — went fishing as a child. It is also one of the many places that he fondly reminisces about in his autobiographical show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Here Comes Halloween
description: And with it, Halloween traditions.
content: Welcome. Outside my Brooklyn building, a life-size witch dangles an alarmingly lifelike orange tabby by one foot over a bubbling cauldron. Enter the building and a skeleton dressed as a butler stands by the elevator, proffering a bowl of mini Kit Kats. You’ll tiptoe around all manner of rubber rodent and spider en route to the mailboxes. It’s Halloween season and my landlord does not mess around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Atlanta Blasts Its Way to a Win, but Loses an Ace
description: The Braves’ offense pounded Houston’s Framber Valdez, but Atlanta will have to scramble after Charlie Morton was knocked out of the remainder of the World Series.
content: HOUSTON — Atlanta stepped into its first World Series since 1999 sharply, quickly and memorably. Jorge Soler blasted Framber Valdez’s third pitch of the game deep over the left-field fence, putting an immediate charge into the 117th World Series: It was the first time in Series history that the first batter of the game homered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: New Guidance Bars Immigration Enforcement in ‘Protected Areas’
description: The Biden administration included schools, hospitals, parades and places of worship on a list of areas off limits to immigration arrests or other types of enforcement.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Biden administration on Wednesday designated the nation’s schools and hospitals, as well as a wide array of other locations, off limits to immigration enforcement, the latest sign that it is committed to protecting millions of undocumented residents from deportation while efforts to offer them a path to legalization remain stalled in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Friedman and Maria Ponomarenko
title: To Rein In Abuse by the Police, Lawmakers Must Do What the Supreme Court Will Not
description: The court has abdicated its responsibility to regulate police behavior.
content: Last week, in two unsigned opinions, the Supreme Court showed its disdain for police reform. The two cases, part of the court’s so-called shadow docket, were decided without public briefing or argument. Taken together, they create an almost insurmountable barrier to holding police officers responsible for violating people’s constitutional rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain prepares for a post-pandemic economy, and keeps spending.
description: “A new age of optimism” is coming, said Chancellor Rishi Sunak, while inflation and shortages still bedevil the country.
content: LONDON — Britain’s top finance official laid out a vision for the country’s post-pandemic economy on Wednesday as he announced plans to spend on education, the National Health Service and job skills. But his plans risk being overshadowed by the recent rise in inflation and supply chain disruptions that are weighing on the pandemic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Facebook, Show Us the Mess
description: Candid looks at the inner workings of influential tech companies shouldn’t be so rare.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Julia Jacobs and Simon Romero
title: Dave Halls, the assistant director, said he did not thoroughly check the gun he handed to Alec Baldwin, according to an affidavit.
description: He had declared the firearm a “cold gun,” according to court documents, indicating that it contained no live rounds and was safe to handle.
content: Dave Halls, the assistant director on the film “Rust,” told an investigator that he had not checked all of the rounds in the gun he handed to Alec Baldwin, as he should have, according to an affidavit released Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lauren Keiles
title: I Fell in Love With Motorcycles. But Could I Ever Love Sturgis?
description: A New Yorker who started riding during the pandemic travels to the heart of biker culture.
content: In order to join one of the private Facebook groups for the 81st annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, I had to agree to 10 rules. Seven addressed matters of basic netiquette — respect, courtesy, bullying, privacy, solicitation (both kinds). Two were apolitical in ways that felt extremely political: “NO COVID COMMENTS” and “ABSOLUTELY NO POLITICS … YOU WILL BE DELETED!” The last concerned what is known as “trailering,” or towing your motorcycle out to Sturgis. “NO TRAILER BASHING!” the rule proclaimed. “YOU WILL BE REMOVED.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in Canada: A Restored 19th-Century Farmhouse in Quebec
description: In and around Quebec City, homes remain more attainable than in larger Canadian cities, especially in the struggling downtown core.
content: Built in 1835 in a traditional Quebec architectural style, this historic home sits on 1.76 wooded acres in the northwestern Quebec City borough of Haute-St.-Charles. The three-level house was restored and expanded by its current owners, who bought it in 2006.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson
title: An Artist’s Life in Objects, From a Warhol Print to a Postmodern Lamp
description: At his Connecticut studio, Peter Halley works among an eclectic collection of furniture and art infused with personal memories.
content: In the 1980s, the artist Peter Halley helped ignite New York’s East Village art scene alongside contemporaries like Jeff Koons and Ashley Bickerton. In 1996, he co-founded the influential arts and culture magazine Index. And between 2002 and 2011, he served as the director of Yale’s M.F.A. painting program. But he is best known for his often gargantuan neon abstract canvases, which he has made in subtly varying forms for four decades (a show of his recent works is currently on view at Dallas Contemporary). Comprising cell-like shapes connected by “conduits,” his paintings are at once luminous and austere, with textured surfaces he laboriously builds up using layers of acrylic frequently mixed with Roll-a-Tex, a surfacing material for houses. A native New Yorker, he works mostly from a 5,000-square-foot studio in West Chelsea, a former industrial building filled with buckets of Day-Glo paint and bins of splattered rollers. But his studio in Connecticut, a modest two-story house wrapped in black-stained shingles that he bought and renovated in 2010, and where he now spends a few days each week, is a very different kind of work space. It serves as both a refuge for making the 17-by-22-inch studies on which his large-scale paintings are based — a meditative process he likens to composing music but with colors instead of chords — and as a memory palace of sorts, filled with furniture and objects from each chapter of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, the Father of ‘Flow,’ Dies at 87
description: His work as a psychologist on the benefits of intense focus led to a global best seller, a term that became a cultural touchstone and new ideas about the path to happiness.
content: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, a Hungarian-born psychologist who showed how everyone from artists to assembly-line workers can be transported to a state of focused contentment by getting caught in the “flow,” a term he coined and later popularized, died on Oct. 20 at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: The Bengals Are Good. Ja’Marr Chase Makes Them Interesting.
description: With Chase on a pace to set a rookie receiving record, Cincinnati has the lead in the A.F.C. North and an offense that can score from anywhere. What?
content: Before receiver Ja’Marr Chase’s arrival, the Cincinnati Bengals may have been the N.F.L.’s most inconsequential franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irina Reyn
title: What Happened After the Most Deadly Antisemitic Attack in American History?
description: In Mark Oppenheimer’s “Squirrel Hill,” he chronicles the aftermath of the Tree of Life shooting and how it affected the tightly knit Pittsburgh Jewish community.
content: SQUIRREL HILLThe Tree of Life Synagogue Shooting and the Soul of a NeighborhoodBy Mark Oppenheimer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cameron Lehman
title: Seeing Life’s Path in the Shape of a Jigsaw Puzzle Piece
description: A jigsaw helped one writer understand his life.
content: Last summer, my sister Alex gave my mother a lovely 491-piece wooden jigsaw of a pastoral Abbott Graves painting. For four months, it sat unopened on the living room table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: He Won the Nobel. Why Are His Books So Hard to Find?
description: After Abdulrazak Gurnah was awarded this year’s Nobel Prize in Literature, he instantly gained a wider international audience, something publishers are now scrambling to accommodate.
content: When Abdulrazak Gurnah released his 10th book, “Afterlives,” last year, his editor was sure it would become his first major best seller. For more than three decades, he had drawn stellar reviews but never gained a large readership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Gangs Rule Much of Haiti. For Many, It Means No Fuel, No Power, No Food.
description: A country in crisis is facing a severe fuel shortage that is pushing it to the brink of collapse.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Gangs blocking Haiti’s ports, choking off fuel shipments. Hospitals on the verge of shutting down as generators run dry, risking the lives of hundreds of children. Cellphone towers going without power, leaving swaths of the country isolated. And an acute hunger crisis growing more severe each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell us your homework tips
description: How does your kid get through it?
content: The school year is underway, and homework sheets, tests and papers are piling up. As we all adjust to a more normal school year, we’d love to hear your best homework tips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What’s the Best Way to Stop Tragic Accidents?
description: The engineer Nancy Leveson has an answer.
content: Tragic accidents have been in the news recently. The actor Alec Baldwin unintentionally shot and killed someone on a movie set after firing a gun that he was told was unloaded. A port explosion in Beirut killed more than 200 people last year. And a new documentary by Frontline, in partnership with The New York Times, examines the two crashes of Boeing 737 Max jets that killed 346 people over the course of four months in 2018 and 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Trooper Charged With Murder in Death of Girl, 11, in a High-Speed Chase
description: The trooper, Christopher Baldner, killed the girl, Monica Goods, by ramming her family’s car after a late-night traffic stop, officials said.
content: Not long before midnight on Dec. 22, a New York state trooper stopped a car for speeding near Kingston, about an hour and a half north of Manhattan. Inside were Tristin Goods, his wife, April, and his daughters, Monica, 11, and Tristina, 12. They were heading north on the New York State Thruway, on their way to visit family for Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: You Can’t Fight City Hall. But You Can Pick Who Runs It.
description: The vegan? The cat lover? A Mets manager?
content: Guess I’m going for the vegan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: A Gay Music Teacher Got Married. The Brooklyn Diocese Fired Him.
description: Matthew LaBanca is bringing attention to a legal loophole that allows religious institutions to exclude people in same-sex civil marriages from jobs by deeming them ministers.
content: Matthew LaBanca said he held two titles while working for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn: music teacher and parish music director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: You Have Election Questions. We Have Answers.
description: Local and statewide elections are being held around the country on Tuesday. Here are some of the Election Day basics.
content: It may not be a presidential or congressional election year, but there are still plenty of races on the ballot on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Starting next year, some immunocompromised people may receive a fourth Covid vaccine dose, the C.D.C. says.
description: The agency said that a booster could be administered at least six months after severely or moderately immunocompromised adults received a third dose of an mRNA vaccine that was authorized over the summer just for them.
content: Some American adults with weakened immune systems who received a third dose of either the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna coronavirus vaccine authorized just for them will become eligible for a fourth shot as a booster next year, according to updated guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: 6 Strategies for Tackling Unfamiliar Words, Suggested by Students
description: Here’s how the winners of our September Vocabulary Challenge became familiar with intriguing words they found in The New York Times.
content: If you read The New York Times for long enough, you’ll probably stumble upon an unfamiliar word. Our September Vocabulary Challenge invited students to seek out that moment of confusion, and then use their best vocabulary sleuthing skills to guess what the word means before looking up its definition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Lisa Friedman
title: Oil Executives to Face Congress on Climate Disinformation
description: The heads of Exxon Mobil, Shell, Chevron and BP will testify Thursday in the first congressional inquiry into industry efforts to hinder action on climate change.
content: Executives of some of the world’s biggest oil and gas companies — Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and Shell — are set to appear before a congressional committee Thursday to address accusations that the industry spent millions of dollars to wage a decades-long disinformation campaign to cast doubt on the science of climate change and to derail action to reduce emissions from burning fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: Hunting for Money, Democrats Rush to Rewrite Tax Code
description: Lawmakers are racing to finalize legislation to pay for new spending initiatives. The process usually takes months, but they are trying to do it in days.
content: WASHINGTON — As they hunt for revenue to pay for their sprawling spending bill and try to unite a fractured caucus, Democrats are attempting to rewrite the United States tax code in a matter of days, proposing the kind of sweeping changes to how America taxes businesses and individuals that would normally take months or years to enact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Final New York Mayoral Debate Descends Into Exchange of Personal Insults
description: The televised confrontation between Eric Adams and Curtis Sliwa a week before Election Day seemed unlikely to change the dynamics of the race.
content: There was talk of schmoozing with murderous gang members, and accusations of hiding money to evade paying child support. Pagliacci, a 19th-century opera about a tortured clown, was invoked. So was Miley Cyrus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: He Unleashed a California Massacre. Should This School Be Named for Him?
description: The founder of the Hastings College of the Law masterminded the killings of hundreds of Native Americans. The school, tribal members and alumni disagree about what should be done now.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: New York Has a New Band of Buzzy Post-Punk Teens: Geese
description: The Brooklyn quintet thought the band would end after high school graduation. Now its debut album, “Projector,” is arriving.
content: Every year, scores of young bands try their hardest to get a label deal that might provide a shot at stardom. For Geese, a Brooklyn-based rock group of five wiry teenage friends, nothing could have been further from their minds. “The band was going to end when we graduated high school,” the guitarist Gus Green said. “None of us thought anything would happen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Merck shares its Covid pill.
content: Merck announced today that it would license its promising Covid-19 pill, allowing the drug to be manufactured and sold cheaply in 105 developing nations, mostly in Africa and Asia. The move could help millions in poorer countries have access to a potentially lifesaving treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: How Social Media Turned ‘Prioritizing Mental Health’ Into a Trap
description: Online fame can be taxing. For one new show, that’s a clever excuse to pay even more attention to a famous family.
content: Back in January, Vogue posted a video documenting a day in the life of a TikTok star named Dixie D’Amelio. Inside her antiseptic luxury apartment, D’Amelio, then 19, scrambles eggs, applies eye shadow and delivers a monologue sprinkled with false bravado. Dixie drafted to fame behind her younger sister, Charli — but while Charli has reigned on TikTok, dancing for 126 million followers, Dixie has assumed the role of whipping girl, earning her own 55 million followers in part by absorbing the public floggings regularly directed at her family. When the Vogue video dropped, commentators diagnosed her as talentless, boring and “a bratty white girl who has leeched off her sister’s fame.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: After 40 Years, Abba Takes a Chance With Its Legacy
description: How one of the biggest pop groups in the world secretly reunited to make a new album and a high-tech stage show featuring digital avatars of themselves — from 1979.
content: STOCKHOLM — The small, tranquil island of Skeppsholmen holds a handful of the Swedish capital’s artistic treasures: Moderna Museet, the theater group Teater Galeasen and the converted red brick warehouse just steps from a waterfront promenade where Benny Andersson has his personal studio. He tucked a packet of the oral tobacco snus in his mouth as Bjorn Ulvaeus sipped coffee in one of its sunbathed rooms earlier this month, the two musicians surrounded by a grand piano, a small selection of synths and an assortment of framed photographs that were perched behind a computer screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: There’s No Dave Chappelle or Hannah Gadsby Without Mort Sahl
description: Before Sahl, who died at 94 on Tuesday, intellectual arguments and controversial stances were off-limits to stand-ups seeking mass acceptance.
content: The first time Mort Sahl appeared in this paper, the theater critic Brooks Atkinson referred to him as a “saloon talker,” because that’s more or less what comics were in the 1950s. They still are, of course. But now they are also philosophers, political sages, conspiracy-mongers, grumps, rebels and outcasts. And no one deserves more credit for the expansion of their portfolio than Mort Sahl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Hellishly Hot Tiny Town Offers ‘Free’ Land. Hundreds of Calls Came In.
description: The town in Australia’s outback, where the temperature can hit 113 degrees Fahrenheit, drew global inquiries when it offered “free” land in a bid to expand its population.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — From the air, the tiny outback town of Quilpie, Queensland, appears to be in the middle of nowhere. It lies on dusty land the color of rust. About 20 kangaroos sometimes take up residence on the school lawn. Summer temperatures can reach 113 degrees Fahrenheit. The nearest city is a 10-hour drive away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Australians will soon be allowed to travel abroad freely if they are fully vaccinated.
description: The eased restrictions will be the first stage in the country’s plan to reopen its borders since slamming them shut in 2020, separating families and leaving thousands stranded overseas.
content: The health minister of Australia announced on Wednesday that fully vaccinated residents would finally be allowed to travel abroad starting on Nov. 1, a year and a half after borders were closed to most ingoing and outgoing travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Tyler Matzek’s Journey From the AirHogs to the World Series
description: The left-hander was once so out of sorts that he attended tryouts with football players and security guards. Now he has one of Atlanta’s most dependable arms.
content: HOUSTON — Atlanta’s most indispensable reliever this postseason was so dispensable three years ago that he could not even find a job in baseball. So he bought a Facebook advertisement and landed with an independent league team in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Netflix Series Stirs Debate About the Lives of Ultra-Orthodox Women
description: The show, “My Unorthodox Life,” tracks the world of Julia Haart, who fled a religious community she found repressive. But some in the community she left say they feel misrepresented.
content: MONSEY, N.Y. — Even at the most liberal flanks of the ultra-Orthodox community here there are daily moments where women live quite differently from men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘Colin in Black & White’ Finds Kaepernick Before He Took a Knee
description: This inventive Netflix docudrama, created by Colin Kaepernick and Ava DuVernay, is a coming-of-age story in the rearview mirror of an activist adulthood.
content: Even if you don’t watch football, you probably know Colin Kaepernick. You likely have seen images of the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback kneeling through the national anthem, a protest against racism that spread among athletes in many sports. You may have seen him as a hot topic on cable news, a target in political rallies or an icon in Nike ads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Eban
title: How Will We Live if Covid Is Here to Stay?
description: Rather than debate how to end the pandemic, we need to debate how to live with it.
content: On May 14, I went for a jog, amazed at my newfound freedom. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had just signed off on the vaccinated shedding their masks outdoors. In Brooklyn’s Prospect Park, on a cloudless spring day, I pondered what seemed like a miraculous paradigm shift: Apparently, I no longer had to fear that my fellow joggers would kill me, or I them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Ahead of a U.N. climate summit, Democrats push to secure policies Biden can promote.
description: Some U.S. lawmakers say they have not given up on the idea of a tax on planet-warming carbon dioxide pollution, which would help meet the president’s promise to sharply cut U.S. emissions.
content: Democrats are still searching for ways to strengthen the climate provisions in President Biden’s environmental and social policy bill just days before he is set to appear at a United Nations climate summit that begins on Sunday in Glasgow, and some lawmakers say they have not given up the push to include a tax on planet-warming carbon dioxide pollution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe and Walt Bogdanich
title: At McKinsey, Widespread Furor Over Work With Planet’s Biggest Polluters
description: A letter signed by more than 1,100 employees has called for change at the consulting firm, which has advised at least 43 of the 100 most environmentally damaging companies.
content: As world leaders prepare to meet in Glasgow next week to address the devastating impact of wildfires, floods and extreme weather caused by rising greenhouse gases, a revolt has been brewing inside the world’s most influential consulting firm, McKinsey & Company, over its support of the planet’s biggest polluters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Rent the Runway, a secondhand fashion site, makes its trading debut.
description: Shares of the clothing rental company, which is trying to rebound from a loss of business during the pandemic, closed below the initial trading price on Wednesday.
content: Rent the Runway started trading on the public markets on Wednesday, testing investor appetite for its apparel rental model in the wake of a brutal year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: An Oath Keeper Was at the Capitol Riot. On Tuesday, He’s on the Ballot.
description: Edward Durfee Jr. is a member of the far-right militia and was at the Capitol on Jan. 6. He is now running for office in New Jersey.
content: Edward Durfee Jr. is many things: a former Marine, a libertarian who distrusts the Federal Reserve and an active member of the far-right Oath Keepers militia who leads the group’s northern New Jersey region and was outside the Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: churlish
description: This word has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachel Quester, Sydney Harper, Robert Jimison, Diana Nguyen, Soraya Shockley, Paige Cowett and Chris Wood
title: The Story of Senator Kyrsten Sinema
description: Many Democrats accuse the Arizona senator of blocking key aspects of President Biden’s agenda. She has remained quiet.
content: As congressional Democrats dramatically scale back the most ambitious social spending bill since the 1960s, they’re placing much of the blame on moderates who have demanded changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Selee
title: On Migration, Will the Americas Succeed Where Europe Could Not?
description: The U.S. should move from a border policy approach to a truly regional and collaborative plan of action.
content: While U.S. attention on immigration has been focused mostly on the large number of Central Americans arriving at the southwestern border over the past few years, the biggest migration flows in the hemisphere are actually happening farther to the south. As the arrival of thousands of Haitians in Del Rio, Texas, last month showed, the United States may well start seeing many more migrants from countries outside the Northern Triangle nations of Central America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley
title: Gun Handed to Alec Baldwin Was Not Thoroughly Checked, Affidavit Says
description: The bullet that killed the cinematographer on the film “Rust” has been recovered, the Santa Fe County Sheriff said, and investigators believe there were more live rounds on the set.
content: SANTA FE, N.M. — Before he handed a revolver that he had declared “cold” to the actor Alec Baldwin on the set of the film “Rust” last week, Dave Halls, an assistant director on the film, told a detective he should have inspected each round in each chamber, according to an affidavit that was released Wednesday. But he did not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Advances Plan for New Settlements, in First for Bennett Era
description: Approved despite the objections of the United States, critics say the new homes will consolidate Israel’s presence in the West Bank and make it harder to create a Palestinian state.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government advanced plans on Wednesday to build more than 3,000 new settlement units in the occupied West Bank, in the first move of its kind since Prime Minister Naftali Bennett succeeded Benjamin Netanyahu in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man to Plead Guilty to Fentanyl Distribution in Death of Mac Miller
description: Under an agreement with federal prosecutors, Stephen Andrew Walter, 48, would serve 17 years in prison for distributing the fentanyl pills that Mr. Miller consumed before he died.
content: A Los Angeles man has agreed to plead guilty to distributing the fentanyl pills that the rapper Mac Miller consumed before he died of an accidental overdose in 2018, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Unequal vaccine access is widening the global economic gap, a U.N. agency says.
description: Wealthier countries with high vaccination rates have had speedier economic recoveries than poorer countries with low vaccination rates, the International Labor Organization said.
content: Unequal access to coronavirus vaccines in developing countries is deepening a “great divergence” between rich and poor nations and slowing economic recovery from the pandemic, the United Nations organization that monitors labor market developments said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Vision Test
description: What message do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Key takeaways from Week 9 of the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
description: A major investor testifies.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The ninth week of testimony in the fraud trial against Elizabeth Holmes raised questions of what risks and responsibilities investors have when they put money into high-growth start-ups like Theranos, Ms. Holmes’s failed blood testing company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With Every Star That Drops Out, Atlanta Casts Another
description: Jorge Soler in the role of Ronald Acuña Jr. A.J. Minter as Charlie Morton. And so it went, with Atlanta rolling to victory in Game 1 of the World Series.
content: HOUSTON — The best player at this World Series watched from a luxury suite at Minute Maid Park on Tuesday night. The second-best player watched from the visiting dugout. The pitcher with the best postseason résumé limped off the field with a broken leg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: How the Dearly Departed Usher Couples Down the Aisle
description: Weddings can be full of tributes to lost loved ones, from a gown embellished with a father’s T-shirt to a huppah draped with a grandmother’s artwork.
content: When Nicole Pellegrino was married on Sept. 4, she wore an opal ring that belonged to her mother, Diane Pellegrino, as her “something blue.” But for Ms. Pellegrino, 28, the tribute to her mother, who died from cancer in August 2017, did not end there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Ian Austen
title: Pope Expresses ‘Willingness’ to Visit Canada for Indigenous Reconciliation
description: A National Truth and Reconciliation Commission has called for a papal apology for abuses at church-run schools for Indigenous children.
content: ROME — The Vatican announced Wednesday that Pope Francis had “indicated his willingness” to visit Canada, after Indigenous leaders in the country had repeatedly demanded that he apologize for the church’s role in residential schools found to be responsible for widespread abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Pastries and Persuasion: How a Global Tax Deal Got Done
description: Over Zoom calls from basements and a breakfast in Brussels, faltering negotiations to remake the world’s tax architecture were revived.
content: WASHINGTON — Over a two-hour breakfast of tea and pastries at the Hotel Amigo in Brussels in July, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen tried to persuade Paschal Donohoe, the Irish finance minister, to abandon Ireland’s rock bottom corporate tax rate and join the global deal the Biden administration was racing to clinch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: David DePatie, Producer Behind the Pink Panther, Dies at 91
description: He and the animator Friz Freleng created the cool feline character he called “the James Bond of the animation world.” The character’s first cartoon won an Oscar.
content: David DePatie and Friz Freleng, the celebrated former Warner Bros. cartoon director, had just opened their animation studio in 1963 when the filmmaker Blake Edwards hired them to design an animated character for a comedy starring Peter Sellers in his first foray as the bumbling Inspector Jacques Clouseau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Dreamliner delays drag down Boeing’s quarterly earnings.
description: The aircraft maker reported $15.3 billion in revenue in the third quarter, up about 8 percent from the same period last year and just below analyst expectations.
content: Boeing said Wednesday that delays in making and delivering its troubled 787 Dreamliner jet will cost the company about $1 billion, weighing the company down even as it benefits from a broad travel resurgence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Why the Virginia Election Is Freaking Democrats Out
description: Democrats don’t seem very motivated to vote.
content: With just under a week to go, the governor’s race in Virginia has gotten tighter than Spanx on a hippo, prompting much agita in Democratic circles. When the Democrats won full control of the statehouse in 2019, for the first time in over 20 years, many political watchers declared the swing state’s blue shift complete. But a recent poll from Monmouth University has the party’s nominee, the former governor Terry McAuliffe, tied with Glenn Youngkin, a former private equity exec who has flirted with the election-fraud lies that are now dogma in Donald Trump’s G.O.P.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Briefs Draw Battle Lines as Texas Abortion Law Nears Supreme Court
description: The justices, who will hear arguments on Monday in two cases challenging the state’s near-total ban, required the parties to file their briefs with extraordinary speed.
content: WASHINGTON — Just days after the Supreme Court agreed to fast-track challenges to a Texas abortion law, setting an exceptionally abbreviated schedule, the parties filed a flurry of briefs on Wednesday attacking and defending the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Anne Barnard
title: How New York Just Took a Big Step Away From Fossil Fuels
description: A decision to reject upgrades of two gas-powered power plants was a big win for climate advocates and was endorsed by Gov. Hochul.
content: In a major win for climate advocates and supporters of wind and solar energy, New York State environmental regulators refused on Wednesday to allow two companies to upgrade their gas-fueled power plants — signaling a newly aggressive approach to ending fossil-fuel emissions that drive climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 2 Officers Are Charged With Murdering Man Who Was Shot Nearly 60 Times
description: Jamarion Robinson was killed in 2016 by members of a fugitive task force when they tried to arrest him in Georgia. Investigators say that he opened fire on the officers.
content: Two Atlanta-area law enforcement officers were charged this week with felony murder for their roles in a confrontation in 2016 with an armed man who was shot nearly 60 times as they tried to arrest him, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: Another Struggle for Long Covid Patients: Disability Benefits
description: President Biden has said the government should help people who continue to experience symptoms long after a coronavirus infection. But qualifying remains a major hurdle.
content: Since she tested positive for the coronavirus in April 2020, Josie Cabrera Taveras has found herself sleeping for up to 15 hours a day, stopping in grocery store aisles to catch her breath, lapsing in and out of consciousness and unable to return to her job as a nanny.

title: The Conservative School Board Strategy
description: Republicans are trying to use suburban fights over critical race theory and pandemic restrictions to energize their voters.
content: Today, we’re looking at how Republicans are trying to use school boards and critical race theory to mobilize their voters. And we explore a free speech debate that is dividing the world of science.

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: B.J. Novak’s Face Is on Products Worldwide. He’s Not Sure Why.
description: An image of the actor appears on an eclectic mix of products from China to Uruguay. “I am too amused to do anything about it,” he said on Instagram.
content: For the last few years, any Swedes who purchased a bottle of Calvin Klein’s Encounter cologne were probably greeted by the piercing gaze of an American actor.

author: By Daniel Victor and Aimee Ortiz
title: That Tainted Halloween Candy Myth Just Won’t Go Away
description: Despite a lack of evidence, warnings about dangers lurking in treats have been an annual ritual for decades. The newest twist involves weed.
content: As children go trick-or-treating, it is exceedingly unlikely that your neighbor will put a razor blade in an apple, poison a wrapped Snickers bar, or, in this year’s version of the same old story, swap THC-laced gummies for regular candy, tricking innocent youngsters into accidentally getting high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: In Defense of ‘Inappropriate’ Kid Movies
description: Not everything needs a tidy moral takeaway.
content: During the darkest, coldest part of our 2020 quarantine, my husband and I turned to the movies of our youth for solace, and we shared them with our 7-year-old and 3-year-old. In a few short weeks we ran through “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off,” “Back to the Future,” “Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade” and the 1991 version of “The Addams Family.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in New York, California and Wyoming
description: A 1765 Georgian house in Kinderhook, a 1927 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles and a cabin in Jackson.
content: Kinderhook, about half an hour south of Albany and two and a half hours north of New York City, is a town with a year-round population of about 8,500 people. This house, a few minutes from the center of town, is known as the Burgoyne House; Gen. John Burgoyne of Britain briefly stayed here as a well-treated prisoner of the Continental Army after his defeat at the Battle of Saratoga. The house was enlarged over the course of the 19th century, but the original facade, including a Palladian window and classic Georgian pediment, remains in excellent condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: This May Be Democrats’ Best Chance to Lower Drug Prices
description: For patients with certain cancers, out-of-pocket spending can exceed $15,000 a year. Legislation could take aim at prices and the amounts Medicare patients are charged.
content: As a diabetes doctor in Baltimore, Sally Pinkstaff saw her patients struggle to pay for insulin. They told her they would take half the normal amount, delay doses, even skip entire months. She would try to help them by adjusting their prescriptions — and sometimes by giving them cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: These 8 Black Women Run Some of the Biggest U.S. Cities
description: Black women achieved a historic milestone as mayors of eight major American cities this year. Political analysts say the record number points to “the age of Black women in politics.”
content: When Kim Janey failed in September to qualify for the mayoral runoff election in Boston, effectively ending her time as the city’s top leader, her political rivals rejoiced and her supporters were dismayed. But her loss affected one group in particular: the collective of seven other Black women who are mayors of large cities. It’s currently a record number.

title: Viktor Bryukhanov, Blamed for the Chernobyl Disaster, Dies at 85
description: In charge of the plant in Ukraine, he was held responsible for the world’s worst nuclear-power disaster and imprisoned.
content: Viktor Bryukhanov, who helped build and manage the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine, where a reactor explosion in 1986 released a radioactive dust cloud over Europe and a humbling fog of finger-pointing and political fallout that contributed to the collapse of the Soviet Union, died on Oct. 13 in Kyiv. title: Review: What Does Ballet Need Now? Not Retro Fantasy.
description: American Ballet Theater’s fall gala featured “ZigZag,” an energetic yet dated premiere by Jessica Lang to songs sung by Tony Bennett.
content: Tony Bennett has long lived by a basic tenet: When everybody zigs, he zags. For him, it’s a mantra — he prefers to go his own way — but as language, it’s also full of motion, like a dance phrase about to be born. For the past couple of years, the choreographer Jessica Lang has found inspiration in pairing his smooth, versatile voice with moving bodies that have been known to zig. And zag.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Melissa Clark’s Instant Pot Knowledge
description: Come for her recipes for pork stew and braised chickpeas, stay for her expert tool tips.
content: Good morning. Melissa Clark took to the pages of The Times this week to give us a terrific look back at her last five years cooking with an electric pressure cooker. Of course there are recipes — for pork stew with red wine and olives (above), for tomato-braised chickpeas with tahini, for rice pudding. But what’s equally invaluable are her troubleshooting tips: how to deal with an ill-seated top, for instance; what to do when you get a burn message on the screen; how to clean your sealing ring; why you should salt your beans before cooking them.
source.name: The New York Times
